    Deadlock Characterization ***

    • ë‹¤ìŒ 4ê°€ì§€ ì¡°ê±´ì´ ë™ì‹œì— ì„±ë¦½í•˜ëŠ” ê²½ìš° deadlock ì´ ë°œìƒ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ
      1. Mutual exclusion

    - Resource-Allocation Graph

    • vertex set V, edge set E ê°€ ìˆì„ ë•Œ
    • V Type

    Basic Facts

    • Cycle ì´ ..
      • ì—†ë‹¤? â†’ Deadlock ì—†ìŒ!!
      • ìˆë‹¤? â†’ 2ê°€ì§€ ê²½ìš°ì˜ ìˆ˜
        1. Res type ë‹¹ í•˜ë‚˜ì˜ instace ë§Œ ìˆë‹¤ë©´ Deadlock

        2. Res type ë‹¹ ì—¬ëŸ¬ê°œì˜ instace ìˆë‹¤ë©´ Deadlock ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±

          (ì§„ì§œ ì¡´ì¬í•˜ëŠ”ì§€ëŠ” ã…ã„¹ ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±ì´ ìˆìœ¼ë‹ˆ í™•ì¸í•´ë³´ì•„ì•¼í•˜ëŠ”ê±°!)

    Case 1. Resource-allocation graph.

    • The sets T, R, and E:
      • *T* = {*T*1, *T*2, *T*3}
      • *R* = {*R*1, *R*2, *R*3, *R*4}
      • *E* = {*T*1 â†’ *R*1, *T*2 â†’ *R*3, *R*1 â†’ *T*2, *R*2 â†’ *T*2, *R*2 â†’ *T*1, *R*3 â†’ *T*3}
    • Resourceinstances:
      • One instance of resource type *R*1
      • Two instances of resource type *R*2
      • One instance of resource type *R*3
      • Three instances of resource type *R*4
    • Threadstates:
      • Thread *T*1 is holding an instance of resource type *R*2 and is waiting for an instance of resource type *R*1.
      • Thread *T*2 is holding an instance of *R*1 and an instance of *R*2 and is waiting for an instance of *R*3.
      • Thread *T*3 is holding an instance of *R*3.

    Case 2. Resource-allocation graph with a deadlock

    • *E* = {â€¦ , *T3* â†’ *R2* } ì¶”ê°€ !
    • Cycle ì¡´ì¬
      1. *T*1 â†’ *R*1 â†’ *T*2 â†’ *R*3 â†’ *T*3 â†’ *R*2 â†’ *T*1
      2. *T*2 â†’ *R*3 â†’ *T*3 â†’ *R*2 â†’ *T*2

      â†’ deadlock ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±

    Case 3. Resource-allocation graph with a cycle but no deadlock

    • ì´ ê²½ìš° T4ê°€ R2 instaceë¥¼ í•´ì§€í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆê¸°ì— T4ê°€ í•´ì§€í•œ ê²ƒì„ T3ê°€ ê°€ì§€ë©´ ë˜ë‹ˆê¹Œ cycle ê¹° ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒ ! â†’ NO DEADLOCK

    Deadlock Avoidance

    - Deadlock Avoidance

    Algorithms

    • $O(mn^2)$
      1. ì´ˆê¸°í™”

        1. Deadlock state íŒë‹¨

    5 Processes : P_0 - P_4; 3 Resource types : A (7 instances), B (2 instances), C (6 instances)
